claim: SnapCap is an example of a retail store.

supporting.text: SnapCap is a retail store because it sells physical products directly to consumers, which is a defining characteristic of retail businesses.

attacks.text: SnapCap is a retail store because it sells physical products directly to consumers, which is a defining characteristic of retail businesses.
SnapCap primarily operates as an online marketplace, not a physical retail store, which contradicts the traditional definition of a retail store.
Selling physical products directly to consumers is not exclusive to retail stores; many wholesale businesses also do this.
Even if SnapCap operates online, it still functions as a retail store because modern retail includes e-commerce platforms.
Wholesale businesses typically sell in bulk to other businesses, not directly to consumers, which distinguishes them from retail stores.

supporting.text: SnapCap is not a retail store because it primarily operates as an online marketplace, lacking a traditional brick-and-mortar presence.

attacks.text: SnapCap is not a retail store because it primarily operates as an online marketplace, lacking a traditional brick-and-mortar presence.
Many retail stores operate primarily online without brick-and-mortar locations, such as Amazon or Wayfair.
The definition of a retail store has evolved to include online marketplaces as they serve the same function of selling goods directly to consumers.
SnapCap may have physical fulfillment centers or pop-up locations, which could qualify it as a retail store.
Some regulatory bodies classify online marketplaces as retail stores if they handle inventory and sales directly.

supporting.text: SnapCap functions as a retail store by offering a variety of goods for purchase, similar to other established retail chains.

attacks.text: SnapCap functions as a retail store by offering a variety of goods for purchase, similar to other established retail chains.
SnapCap primarily operates as an online marketplace, not a physical retail store, which contradicts the traditional definition of a retail store.
Many traditional retail stores also have significant online operations, so the distinction between physical and online retail is becoming blurred.
SnapCap's product offerings are limited to a niche market, unlike general retail stores that cater to a wide range of consumer needs.
Niche retail stores are still considered retail stores as long as they sell goods directly to consumers, regardless of the product range.

supporting.text: SnapCap does not qualify as a retail store because its business model focuses on dropshipping, meaning it does not hold inventory.

attacks.text: SnapCap does not qualify as a retail store because its business model focuses on dropshipping, meaning it does not hold inventory.
Many retail stores operate without holding inventory, such as online marketplaces that fulfill orders via dropshipping.
Traditional definitions of retail stores emphasize direct sales to consumers, not inventory ownership.
Dropshipping businesses often lack control over product quality and shipping times, differentiating them from conventional retail stores.

supporting.text: SnapCap can be considered a retail store as it engages in the sale of products to end-users, fulfilling the core function of retail.

attacks.text: SnapCap can be considered a retail store as it engages in the sale of products to end-users, fulfilling the core function of retail.
SnapCap primarily operates as an online platform, lacking a physical storefront, which is a common characteristic of traditional retail stores.
Many modern retail stores operate both online and offline, and the absence of a physical storefront does not disqualify a business from being considered retail.
SnapCap's business model focuses on subscription-based services rather than direct product sales, which deviates from the typical retail store model.
Subscription-based services often include the sale of products as part of the subscription, which aligns with the retail function of selling products to end-users.

supporting.text: SnapCap is not a retail store because it lacks the physical storefronts and customer service infrastructure typical of retail establishments.

attacks.text: SnapCap is not a retail store because it lacks the physical storefronts and customer service infrastructure typical of retail establishments.
Many retail stores operate exclusively online without physical storefronts, such as Amazon or Wayfair.
Online-only retail stores still maintain customer service infrastructure, such as chatbots, call centers, and return policies.
SnapCap primarily functions as a digital platform for instant photo printing, not a traditional retail store.
Digital platforms selling physical products (like SnapCap) are increasingly classified as retail due to their transactional nature.
